programs.description: Upregulation of hypoxia-adaptive genes promoting glycolytic switch, proangiogenic signaling, autophagy, and therapy resistance; extensive literature implicates ANGPTL4, HILPDA, BNIP3L, NDRG1, TRIB3, LUCAT1 as a hypoxia-adaptive cluster that links metabolic stress to increased invasion, therapy evasion, and immune suppression.

citation.notes: ANGPTL4, HILPDA, BNIP3L, NDRG1 upregulated in hypoxic glioblastoma, promoting glycolytic switch and cell survival.
BNIP3 mediates hypoxia-induced autophagy and resistance to antiangiogenic therapy in GBM.
Hypoxia-regulated genes associate with glioblastoma perivascular microenvironment and tumor progression.

programs.evidence_summary: Robust hypoxia program in GBM involves coordinated upregulation of metabolic adaptation (ANGPTL4, HILPDA), autophagy and stress response genes (BNIP3L, NDRG1, TRIB3), and noncoding RNA modulators (LUCAT1), all producing a TME primed for therapeutic resistance and immune suppression.

citations.notes: Glioblastoma hypoxia transcriptomic responses include these genes and drive poor prognosis.
Autophagy genes mediate GBM adaptation to hypoxia and antiangiogenic therapy.
HIF1A and VEGFA are central to hypoxia signaling, full program also includes DDIT4 and PGF.

programs.description: Coordinated activation of EMT and mesenchymal-associated genes (RUNX2, ITGB3, CAV1, COL5A1, COL13A1, COL24A1, ABI3BP) drives cytoskeletal remodeling, cell migration, and infiltrative tumor behavior in GBM.

citation.notes: RUNX2 and mesenchymal markers are implicated in GBM EMT-like phenotype and invasion.
ITGB3 mediates ECM adhesion and drug resistance in GBM cells.
PHIP, PHLDB2, and integrin complexes regulate adhesion and motility.

programs.evidence_summary: Multiple input genes are key drivers of mesenchymal transition, invasiveness, and cell-ECM interactions; high expression correlates with poor clinical outcomes and enhanced infiltration in malignant glioblastoma.

citations.notes: Mesenchymal gene expression defines invasive GBM subtypes.
ECM–integrin interactions drive drug resistance and migration in GBM.
EMT transcription factors (TWIST1, SNAI2, ZEB1) and fibronectin are central to full mesenchymal program.

programs.description: PTGS2, ANGPTL4, HILPDA, and ITGB3 cluster with hypoxia and angiogenic genes to drive neovascularization, abnormal microvasculature, and support tumor progression in glioblastoma.

citation.notes: ANGPTL4, PTGS2, and integrin gene signatures predict angiogenesis and survival in GBM.
Noncoding RNAs and angiogenic genes modulate glioblastoma vascular microenvironment.

programs.evidence_summary: ANGPTL4, PTGS2, ITGB3, and HILPDA form a core angiogenic program in glioblastoma, underpinning microvascular proliferation and providing survival advantages, documented in both experimental and clinical cohorts.

citations.notes: Multi-gene angiogenesis signature supports GBM prognosis.
Noncoding RNAs regulate angiogenic pathways and vascular niche.
VEGF pathway remains canonical for angiogenesis in GBM.

programs.description: MET acts with ERRFI1 (negative EGFR feedback) and CAV1 to regulate growth factor signaling, promoting proliferation and invasion; feedback disruption is common in glioblastoma and leads to resistance against targeted therapies.

citation.notes: Dysregulated MET and EGFR signaling in glioblastoma drives tumorigenesis and therapy resistance.
EGFR pathway is a major therapeutic target; ERRFI1 contributes to feedback regulation.
CAV1 interfaces with multiple growth factor receptors and signaling complexes in GBM.

programs.evidence_summary: Dysregulation of MET, EGFR, and feedback inhibitors (ERRFI1) is central to malignant glioblastoma biology, facilitating proliferation, invasion, and poor drug response.

citations.notes: MET/EGFR oncogenic synergy is critical in GBM.
CAV1–receptor interactions underpin regulatory pathway complexities.
Epigenetic regulation modifies EGFR pathway feedback.
EGFR amplification and mutation is ubiquitous in GBM.

method.notes: Programs derived by combining pathway-centric and functional genomics evidence with high-confidence transcriptomic signatures in malignant glioblastoma.
